com.freeputer

Class FVM

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.freeputer.FVM
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class FVM
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable

    Class FVM implements the Freeputer Virtual Machine 1.0.

    WARNING

    This is alpha software (see source code for details).

    INTRODUCTION

    The Freeputer Virtual Machine (FVM) is primarily intended to be implemented in assembly language. It is not hard to do so; indeed it is much easier (for an expert in assembly language for a target platform) than using C. This is mainly because C has undefined behaviour and does not expose useful CPU status flags. The reference implementation of the FVM 1.0 is written in x86 assembly language for 32-bit Linux. See 'dev/fvm/x86/src/fvm.s'. It is stable betaware.

    There is now also a portable C implementation of the FVM 1.0. See 'dev/fvm/c/src/fvm.c'. It is a little larger and somewhat slower than the reference implementation but is portable and should run on most devices that gcc can target. It is alpha software.

    A Java FVM implementation should not be your first resort. This Java implementation is about 5 times slower than the reference implementation and might well be 100 or 1000 times larger (that is, including the JRE). On the other hand, this Java implementation is portable and should run on numerous devices that support Java 6 or higher. Also, you might choose to use this Java implementation if you wish to embed Freeputer software modules in a larger Java application (rather than communicating with them remotely as distributed services).

    Before using this Java FVM implementation you should read the 'README.html' file in the Freeputer project root directory for a comprehesive introduction to the Freeputer platform. You should do the Quick Start tutorial therein using the reference implementation.

    USAGE IN JAVA

    The examples below show a few of the many ways that FVM instances can be created and run. They correspond to typical current use of the reference implementation.

    This implementation does not provide all possible constructors. For example, it does not provide a constructor to configure an FVM instance to hard reset (rather than soft reset or halt) when a trap occurs; however, you could very easily achieve that by adding your own constructor and/or slightly modifying the "SYSTEM RESET" section of this class.

    To create an FVM instance:

    
 // Create a small FVM with 16 kB ROM, 16 kB RAM and a zero-sized stdblk 
 FVM fvm16_0kB = new FVM();

 // Create an FVM with 16 MB ROM, 16 MB RAM and a zero-sized stdblk
 FVM fvm16_0MB = new FVM(0x01000000,0);

 // Create an FVM with 16 MB ROM, 16 MB RAM and 16 MB stdblk
 FVM fvm16_16MB = new FVM(0x01000000,0x01000000);

 // Create an FVM sized and configured to run the fvmtest suite.
 // It will have 16 MB ROM, 16 MB RAM, 16 MB stdblk, will append to (rather
 // than truncating) stdtrc when it restarts and it will soft reset
 // rather than halt when a trap occurs.
 FVM fvm16_16MB-sr-append = FVM.getFvmtestInstance();

    To run FVM instances synchronously:

    
 // Create 4 identified FVM instances 
 FVM fvm1 = new FVM(1);
 FVM fvm2 = new FVM(2);
 FVM fvm3 = new FVM(3);
 FVM fvm4 = new FVM(4);

 // Run them sequentially:
 fvm1.run();
 fvm1.getSystemExitCode(); // 0 indicates success
 
 fvm2.run();
 fvm2.getSystemExitCode(); // 0 indicates success
 
 fvm3.run();
 fvm3.getSystemExitCode(); // 0 indicates success 
 
 fvm4.run();
 fvm4.getSystemExitCode(); // 0 indicates success

    Important: For the runs to succeed the following local files must exist:

    
 rom.fp1   rom.fp2    rom.fp3    rom.fp4 
 std.blk1  std.blk2   std.blk3   std.blk4 
 std.imp1  std.imp2   std.imp3   std.imp4

    Each 'rom.fp' file must contain the compiled Freelang program which the respective FVM instance shall run. Each 'std.blk' file represents a standard block device (here an empty file). Each 'std.imp' file represents a standard import device (here an empty file). See DEPLOYMENT below.

    To run FVM instances asynchronously:

    
 // Create 4 identified FVM instances
 FVM fvm1 = new FVM(1);
 FVM fvm2 = new FVM(2);
 FVM fvm3 = new FVM(3);
 FVM fvm4 = new FVM(4);
 
 // Run them concurrently:
 new Thread(fvm1).start();
 new Thread(fvm2).start();    
 new Thread(fvm3).start();
 new Thread(fvm4).start();

 // Determine if runs succeeded
 fvm1.getSystemExitCode(); // null = still running, 0 = success
 fvm2.getSystemExitCode(); // null = still running, 0 = success
 fvm3.getSystemExitCode(); // null = still running, 0 = success
 fvm4.getSystemExitCode(); // null = still running, 0 = success

    Important note: This FVM implementation simply uses System.in and System.out for Freeputer stdin and stdout. This is not appropriate for running co-located FVM instances concurrently unless you intend them to asynchronously share those streams.

    DEPLOYMENT

    To successfully run an FVM instance the following must exist:

    • a 'rom.fp' file containing the compiled Freelang program to be run
    • a 'std.blk' file of the correct size for that instance (can be empty)
    • a 'std.imp' file (can be empty)

    If those files are 'foo/rom.fp', 'foo/std.blk' and 'foo/std.imp' and you have compiled this 'FVM.java' file to 'foo/com/freeputer/FVM.class' then you might run your FVM instance from the 'foo' directory by: java com.freeputer.FVM

    If you specify an fvmID (when you instantiate your FVM instance) then those files must each be suffixed accordingly (e.g. 'rom.fp1', 'std.blk1' and 'std.imp1').

    FURTHER INFORMATION

    For further information please see:

    • the source code of this 'FVM.java' class ('dev/fvm/java/src/com/freeputer/FVM.java')
    • the extensive comments in the reference implementation ('dev/fvm/x86/src/fvm.s')
    • the extensive comments in the C implementation ('dev/fvm/c/src/com/freeputer/fvm.c')
    • the 'README.html' in the Freeputer project root directory
    Version:
    0.1.0.1 alpha for FVM 1.0
    Author:
    Robert Gollagher

      • FVM

        public FVM()
        Constructs a small unidentified FVM instance with no stdblk capacity. 
         Constructs a small VM instance having:
   16 kB RAM, 16 kB ROM, 0-sized stdblk, no memory-mapped devices.
 Typically designated as:
   fvm16_0kB

      • FVM

        public FVM(int fvmID)
        Constructs a small identified FVM instance with no stdblk capacity. 
         Constructs a small VM instance having:
   16 kB RAM, 16 kB ROM, 0-sized stdblk, no memory-mapped devices.
 Typically designated as:
   fvm16_0kB
        Parameters:
        fvmID - the ID for this FVM instance (or null if unidentified)

      • FVM

        public FVM(int arbitraryMemorySize,
           int stdblkSize)
        Constructs an unidentified FVM instance with the specified sizing and having no memory-mapped devices.
        Parameters:
        arbitraryMemorySize - size of ROM in bytes and size of RAM in bytes
        stdblkSize - size of stdblk in bytes (the 'std.blk' file)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if arbitraryMemorySize is 0 or not a power of 2 or not an even multiple of word size; if stdblk size is not either 0 or a power of 2 and an even multiple of word size.

      • FVM

        public FVM(int arbitraryMemorySize,
           int stdblkSize,
           java.lang.Integer fvmID)
        Constructs an FVM instance with the specified sizing and having no memory-mapped devices.
        Parameters:
        arbitraryMemorySize - size of ROM in bytes and size of RAM in bytes
        stdblkSize - size of stdblk in bytes (the 'std.blk' file)
        fvmID - the ID for this FVM instance (or null if unidentified)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if arbitraryMemorySize is 0 or not a power of 2 or not an even multiple of word size; if stdblk size is not either 0 or a power of 2 and an even multiple of word size.

      • FVM

        public FVM(int arbitraryMemorySize,
           int stdblkSize,
           java.lang.Integer fvmID,
           boolean appendStdtrc,
           boolean softResetOnTrap)
    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Constructs an FVM instance with the specified sizing and configuration and having no memory-mapped devices.
        Parameters:
        arbitraryMemorySize - size of ROM in bytes and size of RAM in bytes
        stdblkSize - size of stdblk in bytes (the 'std.blk' file)
        fvmID - the ID for this FVM instance (or null if unidentified)
        appendStdtrc - if true, stdtrc will append not truncate upon FVM restart
        softResetOnTrap - if true, the FVM will soft reset instead of halt upon a trap
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if arbitraryMemorySize is 0 or not a power of 2 or not an even multiple of word size; if stdblk size is not either 0 or a power of 2 and an even multiple of word size.

    • Method Detail

      • getFvmID

        public java.lang.Integer getFvmID()

        Gets the fvmID of this FVM instance.

        Note: the fvmID is not part of the implied FVM 1.0 platform standard. It is simply a convenient means by which this Java implementation can instantiate multiple FVM instances and identify the system resources associated with each instance.

        Returns:
        the fvmID this FVM instance was instantiated with

      • getFvmtestInstance

        public static final FVM getFvmtestInstance()
        Convenience method for instantiating an FVM correctly sized and configured to run the fvmtest suite.
        Returns:
        an FVM ready to use to run the fvmtest suite.

      • getSystemExitCode

        public java.lang.Integer getSystemExitCode()
        Gets the systemExitCode for this FVM instance. A null systemExitCode indicates that the FVM instance has not yet completed its run. 0 indicates success. A non-zero value indicates failure. See the "TRAPS" section of this source code for those failure codes.
        Returns:
        an Integer systemExitCode or null

      • run

        public final void run()

        Run this FVM instance.

        To run synchronously use:

        
 FVM fvm = new FVM();
 fvm.run();

        To run asynchronously use:

        
 FVM fvm = new FVM();
 new Thread(fvm).start();
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)

        Creates and runs a small, simple, default FVM instance.

        For that instance to run successfully there must locally exist 'rom.fp' (containing your compiled Freelang program), 'std.blk' (an empty file) and 'std.imp' (an empty file) in the directory from which you invoke java.

        Modify this method to experiment with creating and running more sophisticated FVM instances synchronoulsy or asynchronously.

        Parameters:
        args - (not used)
